reviewText: Really great Shoot-them up/bullet-hell game. the graphics are clean and the art style is great, the bullet patterns are really great and hard yet not impossible to avoid which makes it more fun and accessible to everyone. the game has also an interesting mechanics like the ability to parry/counter the bullets coming your way, and some enemies have a shield which only breaks if you use your special attack on them then you can hit them with your regular bullets. the soundtrack is also great and suits the game very well. my only minor complaint is sometimes enemies come from the back of the screen without warning which makes them hard to avoid. overall highly recommended for sure.\n\nP.S. it would be awesome to have the option to make only your hitbox appears instead of the whole character.

reviewText:
Yes this is a typical Japanese Shoot'Em Up and Bullet Hell game.
Despite it was made by a Switzerland Indie Developer, it really does have many Japanese elements.
The art, game mechanics and soundtrack really brings the Japanese style game.
The game itself are well-made, got no problem while finishing the game. They even made the buttom HUD went transparent whenever you fly too close to the HUD.

The game does made me said なんでやねん!? (Read: What the!?)
It's a short game, there is only 3 levels to beat but that doesn't mean this game is easy to beat.
Each level consist of horde of minions, mini-boss, and the boss.
The difficulty from stage 1 to stage 2 went up higher than I expected, thanks god I have played Touhou" before.
And the stage 3 is a hassle because the minions move faster and you have to depend on the enemies bullet to destroy the blue shield.

Bullet Hell fans might enjoy this!
"

reviewText: For two dollars, Nandeyanen!? - The 1st Sutra is a steal. Don't let the idea that it has only three stages" dissuade you from purchasing it. You'll get more entertainment from Nandeyanen's three stages than you would from games that are twice its length (and far more than twice its price).\n\nWhen it comes to gameplay
date: Nandeyanen!? nails it. Controls are tight and responsive
recommended: and everything necessary for dispatching foes is provided right from the start: standard bullet stream
helpfulPercent: and the ability to "counter" enemy shots. Among these skills
votesHelpful: the "bullet counter" is especially notable for its orginality. Functioning much like a "parry" would in a fighting game--specifically Street Fighter III
votesTotal: for those old enough to remember--a successful counter deflects incoming fire. Managing to deflect a torrent of bullets feels pretty satisfying
votesFunny: and using the other skills efficiently is fun
commentsCount: but you'll have to play on "normal" or "hard" to appreciate the cleverness of Nandeyanen's mechanics. The easy difficulty setting oversimplifies countering bullets
column16: making the game *too* easy.\n\nAs for the game's visuals and music
column17: Nandeyanen!? doesn't miss a beat. The game creatively draws upon Japanese mythology to produce a dream-like
column18: immersive world. The stage backgrounds have a lovely hand-painted look to them
column19: and the sprites populating the stages are vibrant
column20: featuring a degree of animation uncommon in bullet hell shoot 'em ups. The game's soundtrack perfectly compliments its visuals
column21: smoothly blending traditional Japanese instruments and vocals with contemporary beats. I haven't experienced such an effective adaptation of Japanese folklore and music in a game since Okami. As with that classic
column22: some familiarity with Japanese culture may enhance appreciation of the game
column23: but thorough knowledge of all things Japanese is not required for enjoyment. Anyone who enjoys beautiful art and music will more than likely be pleased by the game's unique aesthetic and mystic atmosphere.\n\nTchagata Games really has made something special. Yes
column24: it is a short game. But that's typical of the shoot 'em up genre. What's not typical is that Nandeyanen!? offers not only sound gameplay but  also a well-imagined world that has all the appeal of a folktale. This is clearly a labor love by a small indie team invested in crafting a game worth playing and a tale worth telling.\n\nBuy it."

reviewText: A unique hard-as-balls shmup style game with a brilliant soundtrack and some great visuals. Played it a lot when it was on Xbox Indie Games Live, was impressed by how good it was. Glad to see it make the break to PC!

reviewText: A Parodius-style sh'mup by Swiss people with an amusing Kansai-ben inspired title.\n\nIt's pretty fun and a bit peculiar, easily replayable; and at £1.59 you can't really go wrong can you?

reviewText: This is a pretty mediocre shoot'em up. The music is ok and the game isn't too diffcult. The gameplay mechanics and  the overall pace feel strange (in a bad way). What I really don't like is the art style and the animations. The backgrounds are ok but everything else looks just ugly and amateurish. I wouldn't recommend it. Not even for the low price. There are many much better shoot'em ups to play.

reviewText: Cool setting, unique art style, and great music elevate this above decent bullet hell shooter." Just as short as you'd expect from $1.99

This game is OK. It's kind of typical fair when it comes to bullet hell games and doesn't do any particular thing wrong or right. It's short and if you're a fan of the genre you might like it. The backgrounds are nice looking. The art design isn't my cup of tea, it definitely has that indie feeling to it. Gundomonium collection and Ikaruga are better choices, but since this is so cheap its not so bad a buy.
